\chapter{Overview}
\label{\detokenize{index:overview}}
SeisFlows is a Python waveform inversion package with a growing user base in academia and industry. So far, the package has been used for production runs with a billion or so model parameters and for research on oil and gas exploration, earthquake seismology, and general nonlinear optimization problems.

To provide flexibility, SeisFlows is very modular.  Users are offered choices in each of the following categories:
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
workflow

\item {} 
system

\item {} 
solver

\item {} 
pre-processing

\item {} 
post-processing

\item {} 
nonlinear optimization

\end{itemize}

The thing that ties everything together is the workflow.  Execution of a workflow is equivalent to stepping through the code contained in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{workflow.main}}.  Users are free to customize the default ‘inversion’ and ‘migration’ workflows from the main package.

A number of options exist for system and solver.  By isolating system and solver machinery, users can switch from one application to another with relative ease. For example, if the study area in an earthquake tomography project expands, users can trade a regional Cartesian solver for a global solver.  If a PBS cluster goes offline and a SLURM cluster comes online to replace it, users can trade the PBS system interface for a SLURM system interface.

A selection of ready-to-go system and solver interfaces is provided in the main package.  Through these interfaces, SeisFlows (or prototypes of it) have run on clusters managed by the Department of Defense, Chevron Corp., Total S.A., Princeton University and other universities and institutions.

Users can also choose from various pre-processing and post-processing options. In our terminology, pre-processing consists of signal processing operations performed on seismic traces prior to the gradient computation.  Post-processing consists of regularization or image processing operations carried out after the gradient computation.

If desired functionality is missing from the main package, users can contribute their own classes or overload default ones.


\chapter{Usage}
\label{\detokenize{index:usage}}

\section{Installation}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:installation}}\label{\detokenize{main/usage::doc}}
To install Seisflows, first clone the repository:

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
\PYG{n}{git} \PYG{n}{clone} \PYG{n}{https}\PYG{p}{:}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{github}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{com}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{rmodrak}\PYG{o}{/}\PYG{n}{seisflows}\PYG{o}{.}\PYG{n}{git}
\end{sphinxVerbatim}

Then set environment variables. Add the following lines to \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{.bashrc}} (or modify accordingly if using a shell other than bash):

\begin{sphinxVerbatim}[commandchars=\\\{\}]
export PATH=\PYGZdl{}PATH:/path/to/seisflows/scripts
export PYTHONPATH=\PYGZdl{}PYTHONPATH:/path/to/seisflows
\end{sphinxVerbatim}


\subsection{Software Prerequisites}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:software-prerequisites}}
SeisFlows requires Python 2.7, Numpy, Scipy and Obspy.  Users will need to install these packages before being able to use SeisFlows.

Forward modeling software is also a prerequisite; see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:solver}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Solver Configuration}}}} for more information.


\subsection{Hardware Prerequisites}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:hardware-prerequisites}}
Access to a computer cluster is required for most applications.  Base classes are provided for several common cluster configurations, including PBS and SLURM.  Nonstandard configurations can often be accommodated through modifications to one of the base classes; see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:system}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{System Configuration}}}} for details.


\section{Job Submission}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:job-submission}}\label{\detokenize{main/usage:submission}}
Each job must have it own \sphinxtitleref{working directory} within which users must supply two input files, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}}.

To begin executing a workflow, simply type \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sfrun}} within a working directory. If an \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{inversion}} workflow and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{serial}} system configuration, for example, are specified in the parameters file, the inversion will begin executing immediately in serial. If a PBS, SLURM, or LSF system configuration is specified instead, execution may wait until required resources become available.

Once the workflow starts running, status information is displayed to the terminal or to the file \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{output.log}}.  By default, updated models and other inversion results are output to the working directory.


\section{Solver Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:solver-configuration}}\label{\detokenize{main/usage:solver}}
SeisFlows includes Python interfaces for SPECFEM2D, SPECFEM3D, and SPECFEM3D\_GLOBE.  While the Python interfaces are part of the SeisFlows package, the solver source code must be downloaded separately through GitHub.

After downloading the solver source code, users must configure and compile it, following the instructions in the solver user manual. Summarized briefly, the configuration and compilation procedure is:

Prior to compilation, users need to run the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configure}} script and prepare input files such as
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
parameter file

\item {} 
source file

\item {} 
stations file.

\end{itemize}

To successfully run the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{configure}}, you may need to install compilers, libraries, and other software in your environment.

The result of compilation is a set of binary executables, such as
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
mesher

\item {} 
solver

\item {} 
smoothing utility

\item {} 
summing utility.

\end{itemize}

After compilation, solver input files must be gathered together in one directory and solver executables in another.  The absolute paths to the directories containing input files and executables must be given in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}}.


\subsection{Writing Custom Solver Interfaces}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:writing-custom-solver-interfaces}}
Besides SPECFEM2D, SPECFEM3D, and SPECFEM3D\_GLOBE, SeisFlows can interface with other solvers capable of running forward and adjoint simulations. Users unaffiliated with the main SeisFlows developers have succeeded in interfacing with, for example, their own finite difference solvers.  For information about writing custom solver interfaces, see {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:developer}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Developer Reference}}}}.


\subsection{Design Philosophy}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:design-philosophy}}
Integration of the solver with the other workflow components can be challenging. Here we try to give an idea of the issues involved from both a developer and a user standpoint.
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
Solver computations account for most of the cost of an inversion. As a result, the solver must be written in an efficient compiled language, and wrappers must be written to integrate the compiled code with other software components.

\item {} 
There is currently no mechanism for automatically compiling executables for SPECFEM2D, SPECFEM3D, or SPECFEM3D\_GLOBE. Users must prepare their own SPECFEM input files and then follow the compilation procedure in the SPECFEM documentation.

\item {} 
As described above {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:submission}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Job Submission}}}}, SeisFlows uses two input files, \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}}.  Problems could arise if parameters from SeisFlows input files conflict with parameters from solver input file. Users must make sure that there are no conflicts between SeisFlows parameters and solver parameters.

\item {} 
In the solver routines, it’s natural to represent velocity models as dictionaries, with different keys corresponding to different material parameters.  In the optimization routines, it’s natural to represent velocity models as vectors. To convert back and forth between these two representations, a pair of utility functions\textendash{}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{split}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{merge}}\textendash{}are included in solver.base.

\end{itemize}


\section{System Configuration}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:system-configuration}}\label{\detokenize{main/usage:system}}
SeisFlows can run on SLURM, PBS, and LSF clusters, as well as, for very small problems, laptops or desktops.  A list of available system interface classes follows. By hiding environment details behind a python interface layer, these classes provide a consistent command set across different computing environments.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{PBS\_SM} - For small inversions on PBS clusters. All resources are allocated at the beginning and all simulations are run within a single job.  Requires that individual wavefield simulations run each on a single core, making this option suitable for small 2D inversions only.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{PBS\_LG} - For large inversions on PBS clusters. The work of the inversion is divided between multiple jobs that are coordinated by a single long-running master job. Resources are allocated on a per simulation basis.  Suitable for small to medium 3D inversions in which individual wavefield simulation span several or more nodes.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{SLURM\_SM} - For small inversions on SLURM clusters. All resources are allocated at the beginning and all simulations are run within a single job.  Requires that each individual wavefield simulation runs only a single core, making this option suitable for small 2D inversions only.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{SLURM\_LG} - For large inversions on SLURM clusters. The work of the inversion is divided between multiple jobs that are coordinated by a single long-running master job. Resources are allocated on a per simulation basis. Suitable for 3D inversions in which individual wavefield simulation span several or more nodes.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{SERIAL} - Tasks that are normally carried out in parallel are instead carried out one at a time. Useful for debugging, but not much else.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{MULTITHREADED} - On desktops or laptops with multiple cores, allows embarrassingly parallel tasks to be carried out several at a time, rather than one at a time.  Can be used to run small 2D inversions on a laptop or desktop.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{LSF\_SM} - Same as SLURM\_SM and PBS\_SM, except for LSF clusters.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{LSF\_LG} - Same as SLURM\_LG and PBS\_LG, except for LSF clusters.


\subsection{Writing Custom System Interfaces}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:writing-custom-system-interfaces}}
If your needs are more specialized, please view \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.system}} source code to get a sense for how to write your own custom system interfaces. In our experience, system interfaces require no more than a few hundred lines of code, so writing your own is generally possible once you are familiar with the SeisFlows framework and your own cluster environment.


\subsection{Design Philosophy}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:id1}}
To make SeisFlows work across different environments, our approach is to wrap system commands with a thin Python layer.  To handle job submission, for example, we wrap the PBS command \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{qsub}} and the SLURM command \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{sbatch}} with a  python utility called \sphinxtitleref{system.submit}.  The result is a consistent python interface across different clusters.

Filesystem settings can be adjusted by modifying values in the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PATH}} dictionary, which is populated from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}}.  Output files and temporary files, by default, are written to the working directory.  If a value for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PATH.SCRATCH}} is supplied, temporary files are written there instead.  If each compute node has its own local filesystem, a value for \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PATH.LOCAL}} can be supplied so that temporary files required only for a local process need not be written to the global filesystem.

As the size of an inversion grows, scalability and fault tolerance become increasingly important.  If a single forward simulation spans more than one node, users must select \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pbs\_lg}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{slurm\_lg}} system configurations in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}}.  If a forward simulation fits onto a single node, users should select \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{pbs\_sm}} or \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{slurm\_sm}} instead.

In SeisFlows, the overall approach to solving system interface problems is to use lightweight Python wrappers.  For complex cluster configurations, heavier-weight solutions may be required.  Users are referred to SAGA or Pegasus projects for ideas.


\section{Developer Reference}
\label{\detokenize{main/usage:developer-reference}}\label{\detokenize{main/usage:developer}}
To allow classes to work with one another, each must conform to an established interface.  This means certain classes must implement certain methods, with specified input and output.  Required methods include
\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{setup}} methods are generic methods, called from the \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{main}} workflow script and meant to provide users the flexibility to perform any required setup tasks.

\item {} 
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{check}} methods are the default mechanism for parameter declaration and checking and are called just once, prior to a job being submitted through the scheduler.

\end{itemize}

Besides required methods, classes may include any number of private methods or utility functions.


\chapter{Executable}
\label{\detokenize{index:executable}}
Seisflows provides several executable Python scripts in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/path/to/seisflows/scripts}}. As the PATH has already been added to environmental varibales, thereby can be executed in any directory.

Tests checking module importing, system, and optimization are also provided in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{/path/to/seisflows/tests}}. It’s recommmended to past these tests prior to other projects.


\section{Scripts}
\label{\detokenize{main/executable:scripts}}\label{\detokenize{main/executable::doc}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
sfrun (sfsubmit): Workflow submission scripts.

\item {} 
plotgll: Plots GLL model read from SPECFEM2D Fortran binary file

\item {} 
sfclean: Delete directories output, output.stat, output.optim
and scratch in the current directory

\item {} 
sfresume: Resume current submitted workflow.

\item {} 
sfexample: Run seisflows example. \sphinxstylestrong{Currently not available}.

\end{itemize}


\section{Tests}
\label{\detokenize{main/executable:tests}}\begin{itemize}
\item {} 
run\_test\_system: Test parallelizaiton environment.

\item {} 
run\_test\_import: Testing seisflows module importing.

\item {} 
run\_test\_optimize:

\item {} 
run\_test\_preprocess:

\item {} 
run\_test\_tools:

\end{itemize}


\chapter{Designing Project}
\label{\detokenize{index:designing-project}}
Before submitting jobs to the local server, parameters defined in \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}} and \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{path.py}} require a careful check, avoiding any unnecessary workload.


\section{Parameter Files: \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}}}
\label{\detokenize{main/design_project:parameter-files-parameters-py}}\label{\detokenize{main/design_project::doc}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{parameters.py}} contains a list of parameter names and values. Prior to a job being submitted, parameters are checked so that errors can be detected without loss of queue time or wall time. Parameters are stored in a dictionary that is accessible from anywhere in the Python code. By convention, all parameter names must be upper case. Parameter values can be floats, integers, strings or any other Python data type. Parameters can be listed in any order.

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{General}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{TITLE}}}] \leavevmode
Project title.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{WORKFLOW}}}] \leavevmode
Workflow specified for seisflows. ‘inversion’ and ‘migration’ are currently supported.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SOLVER}}}] \leavevmode
Time domain solver specified for seisflows. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:solver}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Solver Configuration}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:sfsolver}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.solver package}}}} for supported options.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SYSTEM}}}] \leavevmode
System type supported for seisflows. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/usage:system}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{System Configuration}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:sfsystem}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.system package}}}} for supported options..

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{OPTIMIZE}}}] \leavevmode
Optimization method used for inversion. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.optimize:sfoptimize}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.optimize package}}}} for supported options.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PREPROCESS}}}] \leavevmode
Preprocessing workflow specified. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.preprocess:sfpreprocess}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.preprocess package}}}} for supported options.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{POSTPROCESS}}}] \leavevmode
Postprocessing workflow specified. ‘base’ needs to be specified.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MISFIT}}}] \leavevmode
Type of misfit for evaluation. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:sfmisfit}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.plugins.misfit module}}}} for supported options.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MATERIALS}}}] \leavevmode
Materials of simulation domain. ‘Elastic’ and ‘Acoustic’ are currently supported. See seisflows.solver.base.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Workflow}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BEGIN}}}] \leavevmode
First iteration index.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{END}}}] \leavevmode
Last iteration index.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NREC}}}] \leavevmode
Number of receivers.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NSRC}}}] \leavevmode
Number of sources. SEM source file needs to be stored with a six-digit index suffix.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SAVEMODEL}}}] \leavevmode
Frequency of saving model. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} by default.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SAVEGRADIENT}}}] \leavevmode
Frequency of saving gradient. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{1}} by default.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SAVEKERNELS}}}] \leavevmode
Frequency of saving kernels. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} by default.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SAVETRACES}}}] \leavevmode
Frequency of saving traces. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} by default.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SAVERESIDUALS}}}] \leavevmode
Frequency of saving residuals. \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{0}} by default.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Preprocessing}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FORMAT}}}] \leavevmode
Data file format.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{CHANNELS}}}] \leavevmode
Data channels. Currenly, ‘su’, or ‘SU’ need to be specified.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NORMALIZE}}}] \leavevmode
Apply normalization for traces. ‘NormalizeEventsL1’, ‘NormalizeEventsL2’, ‘NormalizeTracesL1’, ‘NormalizeTracesL2’ are currently supported. See seisflows.preprocess.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Filter}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{BANDPASS}}}] \leavevmode
Boolean type bandpass switch for traces.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FILTER}}}] \leavevmode
Type of filter used. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.preprocess:sfpreprocess}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.preprocess package}}}} for supported options.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FREQMIN}}}] \leavevmode
Low frequency corner.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{FREQMAX}}}] \leavevmode
High frequency corner.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Mute}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MUTE}}}] \leavevmode
List type switch for trace mute. {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.preprocess:sfpreprocess}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.preprocess package}}}} for supported options.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Postprocessing}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SMOOTH}}}] \leavevmode
Smoothing radius. See \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{xsmooth\_sem}} for usage.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Optimization}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRECOND}}}] \leavevmode
Preconditioner type. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{main/design_project:path}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{Path Files: paths.py}}}} and {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.preconds:sfprecond}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.plugins.preconds.diagonal module}}}}.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{STEPMAX}}}] \leavevmode
Maximum trial steps

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{Solver}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NT}}}] \leavevmode
Number of time steps defined in Par\_file.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DT}}}] \leavevmode
Time step defined in Par\_file.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{F0}}}] \leavevmode
Dominant frequency defined in SOURCE.

\end{description}\end{quote}

\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{System}}
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NTASK}}}] \leavevmode
Number of tasks submitted. Currently, \sphinxstylestrong{NTASK} must satisfy 1 \textless{}= NTASK \textless{}= NSRC.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{NPROC}}}] \leavevmode
Number of processors.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MPIEXEC}}}] \leavevmode
MPI executable prefix, e.g., \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{mpirun -np 13}}. Note for a space at the end of the string, as seisflows concatenates the prefix with SPECFEM executable command.

\end{description}\end{quote}


\section{Path Files: \sphinxstyleliteralintitle{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}}}
\label{\detokenize{main/design_project:path-files-paths-py}}\label{\detokenize{main/design_project:path}}
\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{paths.py}} contains a list of path names and values. Prior to a job being submitted, paths are checked so that errors can be detected without loss of queue time or wall time. Paths are stored in a dictionary that is accessible from anywhere in the Python code. By convention, all names must be upper case, and all values must be absolute paths. Paths can be listed in any order.
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DATA}}}] \leavevmode
PATH contains seismic data if field data is used for inversion. Data of difference sources should be stored in separate folder. If \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DATA}} directory does not exist, seisflows would automatically generate synthetic data using model from \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MODEL\_TRUE}}.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MODEL\_INIT}}}] \leavevmode
PATH contains model file for initial iteraion.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MODEL\_TRUE}}}] \leavevmode
PATH contains true model for generating synthetic data.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{PRECOND}}}] \leavevmode
PATH to user supplied diagonal preconditioner. Seisflows will rescale model parameters based on user supplied weights. See {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.preconds:sfprecond}]{\sphinxcrossref{\DUrole{std,std-ref}{seisflows.plugins.preconds.diagonal module}}}}.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{MASK}}}] \leavevmode
PATH to mask file for gradient scaling. Mask needs to be stored mimicking the file format in which models are stored.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SPECFEM\_DATA}}}] \leavevmode
PATH to SPECFEM \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{DATA}} directory which contians Par\_file, SOURCE, and other necessary inputs.

\item[{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{SPECFEM\_BIN}}}] \leavevmode
PATH to SPECFEM \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{bin}} directory which contains binary executable command of SPECFEM solver.

\end{description}\end{quote}


\chapter{Example}
\label{\detokenize{index:example}}

\section{Examples: Available For Download}
\label{\detokenize{main/example:examples-available-for-download}}\label{\detokenize{main/example::doc}}
We have prepared a 2D waveform inversion example that is inexpensive enough to run on almost any laptop, desktop, or cluster.

Some additional examples are available for download.  Please review the instructions for the 2D checkerboard test case to get a sense for how to run these other inversions.

Some 2D examples based on the Marmousi model are available \sphinxhref{http://tigress-web.princeton.edu/~rmodrak/2dElastic}{here}.

A 3D Cartesian checkerboard example is available \sphinxhref{http://tigress-web.princeton.edu/~rmodrak/3dElastic}{here}.

A 3D global 1-chunk example is available \sphinxhref{http://tigress-web.princeton.edu/~rmodrak/ExamplesGlobal}{here}. Please note, the compressed archive for this example is very large (\textgreater{} 0.5 GB). \sphinxstyleemphasis{{[}No longer available because of file size.{]}}

At a minimimum, one processer is required for the 2D Marmousi examples, 16 processors are required for the 3D Cartesian example, and 64 processors are required for the global 1-chunk example.  See \sphinxhref{http://seisflows.readthedocs.org/en/latest/usage/usage.html\#system-configuration}{here} for more information about running inversions in parallel.

\sphinxstyleemphasis{Note: File hosting services are provided by my alma mater.  The download server may become temporarily unavailable due to system maintenance or permanently unavailable due to expiration of my account.}

\label{\detokenize{main/example:examples-available-locally}}
Users with accounts on “tiger.princeton.edu” can run the following inversions without having to download files or recompile executables.

\subsection{seisflows.optimize.base module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.optimize:module-seisflows.optimize.base}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.optimize:seisflows-optimize-base-module}}\index{seisflows.optimize.base (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.optimize.base}\spxextra{module}}\index{base (class in seisflows.optimize.base)@\spxentry{base}\spxextra{class in seisflows.optimize.base}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.optimize:seisflows.optimize.base.base}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.optimize.base.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{base}}}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

Nonlinear optimization abstract base class

Base class on top of which steepest descent, nonlinear conjugate, quasi-
Newton and Newton methods can be implemented.  Includes methods for
both search direction and line search.

To reduce memory overhead, vectors are read from disk rather than passed
from calling routines. For example, at the beginning of compute\_direction
the current gradient is  read from  ‘g\_new’ and the resulting search
direction is written to ‘p\_new’. As the inversion progresses, other
information is stored as well.
\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode
m\_new - current model
m\_old - previous model
m\_try - line search model
f\_new - current objective function value
f\_old - previous objective function value
f\_try - line search function value
g\_new - current gradient direction
g\_old - previous gradient direction
p\_new - current search direction
p\_old - previous search direction

\end{description}
\index{check() (seisflows.optimize.base.base method)@\spxentry{check()}\spxextra{seisflows.optimize.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.optimize:seisflows.optimize.base.base.check}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{check}}}{}{}

\end{fulllineitems}

After failed line search, determines if restart is worthwhile by
checking, in effect, if search direction was the same as gradient
direction

\subsubsection{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.backtrack module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:module-seisflows.plugins.line_search.backtrack}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:seisflows-plugins-line-search-backtrack-module}}\index{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.backtrack (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.backtrack}\spxextra{module}}\index{Backtrack (class in seisflows.plugins.line\_search.backtrack)@\spxentry{Backtrack}\spxextra{class in seisflows.plugins.line\_search.backtrack}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:seisflows.plugins.line_search.bracket.Bracket}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.bracket.Bracket}}}}}

Implements backtracking linesearch
\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode
x - list of step lenths from current line search
f - correpsonding list of function values
gtg - dot product of gradient with itself
gtp - dot product of gradient and search direction

\item[{Status codes}] \leavevmode
status \textgreater{} 0  : finished
status == 0 : not finished
status \textless{} 0  : failed

\end{description}

\subsubsection{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:module-seisflows.plugins.line_search.base}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:seisflows-plugins-line-search-base-module}}\index{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base}\spxextra{module}}\index{Base (class in seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base)@\spxentry{Base}\spxextra{class in seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins.line_search:seisflows.plugins.line_search.base.Base}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{Base}}}{\emph{step\_count\_max=10}, \emph{step\_len\_max=inf}, \emph{path='/Users/niyiyu/Documents/GitHub/seisflows/docs'}}{}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

Abstract base class for line search
\begin{description}
\item[{Variables}] \leavevmode
x - list of step lenths from current line search
f - correpsonding list of function values
m - how many step lengths in current line search?
n - how many model updates in optimization problem?
gtg - dot product of gradient with itself
gtp - dot product of gradient and search direction

\item[{Status codes}] \leavevmode
status \textgreater{} 0  : finished
status == 0 : not finished
status \textless{} 0  : failed

\end{description}
\index{calculate\_step() (seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base.Base method)@\spxentry{calculate\_step()}\spxextra{seisflows.plugins.line\_search.base.Base method}}

Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}

Limited-memory BFGS algorithm

Includes optional safeguards: periodic restarting and descent
conditions.

To conserve memory, most vectors are read from disk rather than
passed from a calling routine.

\subsection{seisflows.plugins.readers module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:module-seisflows.plugins.readers}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows-plugins-readers-module}}\index{seisflows.plugins.readers (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.plugins.readers}\spxextra{module}}\index{ascii() (in module seisflows.plugins.readers)@\spxentry{ascii()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.plugins.readers}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows.plugins.readers.ascii}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.readers.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{ascii}}}{\emph{path}, \emph{filenames}}{}
Reads SPECFEM3D-style ascii data

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{readBigSuFile() (in module seisflows.plugins.readers)@\spxentry{readBigSuFile()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.plugins.readers}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows.plugins.readers.readBigSuFile}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.readers.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{readBigSuFile}}}{\emph{nameOfFile}, \emph{nt}, \emph{format='SU'}, \emph{byteorder='\textless{}'}}{}
This function is a hack to read .su file containing too many samples
per traces.
In the su format only 2 bytes per trace are dedicated to encoding for
the number of samples (as signed int, see:
\sphinxurl{http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2017-March/002359.html}).
Even if it’s an old format it’s still extremely stupid.
This prove the lack of vision the designer of this format had at that
time. They could have chosen 8 bytes or 16 bytes it was no big deal…
They’ve cost me a day’s work.
But let us forget about the past. This limits the size of the
traces to 32768 samples (NSTEP beween -32768 to 32768). Let us now
suppose that we have NSTEP = 80000 samples per trace. We still want to
use Obspy. The problem is that the NSTEP written in the .su file does
not make any sense anymore and it is read by the obspy.read function!
We thus rewrote a quick version of this function replacing the number
of point by PAR.NT
It is mainly copy-pasted from Obspy source code.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{su() (in module seisflows.plugins.readers)@\spxentry{su()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.plugins.readers}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows.plugins.readers.su}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.readers.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{su}}}{\emph{path}, \emph{filename}}{}
Reads Seismic Unix files.
Hardwired ‘’

Function readBigSuFile is a hack to read su file containing too many
samples per trace.
In the su format only 2 bytes per trace are dedicated to encoding for
the number of samples (as signed int, see:
\sphinxurl{http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2017-March/002359.html}).
Even if it’s an old format it’s still extremely stupid.
This proove the lack of vision the designer of this format had at that
time. They could have chosen 8 bytes or 16 bytes it was no big deal…
They’ve cost me a day’s work.
But let us forget about the past. This limits the size of the
traces to 32768 samples (NSTEP beween -32768 to 32768). Let us now
suppose that we have NSTEP = 40000 samples per trace. We still want to
use Obspy. The problem is that the NSTEP written in the .su file does
not make any sense anymore and it is read by the obspy.read function!
We thus rewrote a quick version of this function from Obspy replacing
the number of point by PAR.NT

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{su() (in module seisflows.plugins.writers)@\spxentry{su()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.plugins.writers}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows.plugins.writers.su}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.writers.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{su}}}{\emph{stream}, \emph{path}, \emph{filename}}{}
Write Seismic Unix files.
Function writeBigSuFile is a hack to write a .su file when the number
of samples per trace is two big.
In the su format only 2 bytes per trace are dedicated to encoding for
the number of samples (as signed int, see:
\sphinxurl{http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2017-March/002359.html}).
Even if it’s an old format it’s still extremely stupid.
This proove the lack of vision the designer of this format had at that
time. They could have chosen 8 bytes or 16 bytes it was no big deal…
They’ve cost me a day’s work.
But let us forget about the past. This limits the size of the
traces in the header to maximum 32768.
We use Obspy to write the file with dummy values there instead of the
real number of sample (that we now anyway : it is PAR.NT).
We thus rewrote a quick version of this function from Obspy replacing
the number of point by PAR.NT

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{writeBigSuFile() (in module seisflows.plugins.writers)@\spxentry{writeBigSuFile()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.plugins.writers}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.plugins:seisflows.plugins.writers.writeBigSuFile}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.plugins.writers.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{writeBigSuFile}}}{\emph{stream}, \emph{path}, \emph{byteorder='\textless{}'}}{}
This function is a hack to write a .su file when the number
of samples per trace is two big.
In the su format only 2 bytes per trace are dedicated to encoding for
the number of samples (as signed int, see:
\sphinxurl{http://lists.swapbytes.de/archives/obspy-users/2017-March/002359.html}).
Even if it’s an old format it’s still extremely stupid.
This proove the lack of vision the designer of this format had at that
time. They could have chosen 8 bytes or 16 bytes it was no big deal…
They’ve cost me a day’s work.
But let us forget about the past. This limits the size of the
traces in the header to maximum 32768.
We use Obspy to write the file with dummy values there instead of the
real number of sample (that we now anyway : it is PAR.NT).
We thus rewrote a quick version of this function from Obspy replacing
the number of point by PAR.NT
This is mostly copy-pastes from Obspy source code

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{get\_time\_scheme() (seisflows.preprocess.base.base method)@\spxentry{get\_time\_scheme()}\spxextra{seisflows.preprocess.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.preprocess:seisflows.preprocess.base.base.get_time_scheme}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{get\_time\_scheme}}}{\emph{traces}}{}
FIXME: extract time scheme from trace headers rather than
parameters file.
Note from Alexis Bottero : it is actually better like this in
my opinion because this allows for longer traces to be processed.
Indeed, in su format only 2 bytes are dedicated to the number of
samples which is supposed to be stored as an unsigned int. The
maximum NT which can be stored in the header is then 32762 whereas
there is no limit in principle.

\end{fulllineitems}

\section{seisflows.solver package}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows-solver-package}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:sfsolver}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver::doc}}

\subsection{seisflows.solver.base module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:module-seisflows.solver.base}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows-solver-base-module}}\index{seisflows.solver.base (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.solver.base}\spxextra{module}}\index{base (class in seisflows.solver.base)@\spxentry{base}\spxextra{class in seisflows.solver.base}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.solver.base.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{base}}}
Bases: \sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{object}}
\begin{description}
\item[{Provides an interface through which solver simulations can be set up}] \leavevmode
and run and a parent class for SPECFEM2D, SPECFEM3D and SPECFEM3D\_GLOBE
subclasses

This class supports only acoustic and isotropic elastic inversions.
For additional options, see github.com/rmodrak/seisflows-multiparameter
\begin{description}
\item[{eval\_func, eval\_grad, apply\_hess}] \leavevmode
These methods deal with evaluation of the misfit function or its
derivatives.  Together, they provide the primary interface through
which SeisFlows interacts with SPECFEM2D/3D

\item[{forward, adjoint}] \leavevmode
These methods allow direct access to low-level SPECFEM2D/3D components,
providing an alternative interface through which to interact with the
solver

\end{description}

\item[{setup, generate\_data, generate\_model}] \leavevmode
One-time operations performed at beginning of an inversion or
migration

\item[{initialize\_solver\_directories, initialize\_adjoint\_traces}] \leavevmode\begin{quote}

SPECFEM2D/3D requires a particular directory structure in which to run
and particular file formats for models, data, and parameter files.
These methods help put in place all these prerequisites
\end{quote}
\begin{description}
\item[{load, save}] \leavevmode
For reading and writing SPECFEM2D/3D models and kernels. On the disk,
models and kernels are stored as binary files, and in memory, as
dictionaries with different keys corresponding to different material
parameters

\item[{split, merge}] \leavevmode
Within the solver routines, it is natural to store models as
dictionaries. Within the optimization routines, it is natural to store
models as vectors. Two methods, ‘split’ and ‘merge’, are used to
convert back and forth between these two representations

\item[{combine, smooth}] \leavevmode
Utilities for combining and smoothing kernels

\end{description}

\end{description}
\index{adjoint() (seisflows.solver.base.base method)@\spxentry{adjoint()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{check\_mesh\_properties() (seisflows.solver.base.base method)@\spxentry{check\_mesh\_properties()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base.check_mesh_properties}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{check\_mesh\_properties}}}{\emph{path=None}}{}
path contains binary files such as:
proc000000\_z.bin, proc000000\_x.bin, proc000000\_vs.bin
proc000000\_vp.bin, proc000000\_rho.bin, proc000001\_z.bin,
proc000001\_x.bin, proc000001\_vs.bin …
These will be read to get the number of processors used, the number
of gll points and the coordinates of those points

\end{fulllineitems}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base.check_solver_parameter_files}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{check\_solver\_parameter\_files}}}{}{}

\index{check\_source\_names() (seisflows.solver.base.base method)@\spxentry{check\_source\_names()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base.check_source_names}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{check\_source\_names}}}{}{}
Determines names of sources by applying wildcard rule to user-
supplied input files
If source\_prefix is ‘SOURCE’ and that in specfem DATA folder are
the files SOURCE\_00001, SOURCE\_00002, SOURCE\_00003, …
Then this will build the list names = {[}‘00001’,’00002’,’00003’,…{]}
If, for ex, taskid is 1 the function returns {[}‘00001’, ‘00002’{]}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{initialize\_adjoint\_traces() (seisflows.solver.base.base method)@\spxentry{initialize\_adjoint\_traces()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base.initialize_adjoint_traces}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{initialize\_adjoint\_traces}}}{}{}
Puts in place “adjoint traces” expected by SPECFEM
Adjoint traces are initialized by writing zeros for all channels.
(even the ones that are not actually in use, as required by
specfem) Ex: Ux, Uy, Uz even if only Uy is used
Channels actually in use during an inversion or migration will be
overwritten with nonzero values later on.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{initialize\_solver\_directories() (seisflows.solver.base.base method)@\spxentry{initialize\_solver\_directories()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.base.base method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.base.base.initialize_solver_directories}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{initialize\_solver\_directories}}}{}{}
Creates directory structure expected by SPECFEM3D, copies
executables, and prepares input files. Executables must be supplied
by user as there is currently no mechanism for automatically
compiling from source.

\end{fulllineitems}

Loads SPECFEM2D/3D models or kernels
\begin{quote}\begin{description}
\item[{Input path :}] \leavevmode
directory from which model is read

\item[{Input parameters :}] \leavevmode
list of material parameters to be read

\item[{Input prefix :}] \leavevmode
optional filename prefix

\item[{Input suffix :}] \leavevmode
optional filename suffix, eg ‘\_kernel’

\item[{Output dict :}] \leavevmode
model or kernels indexed by material parameter
and processor rank, ie dict{[}parameter{]}{[}iproc{]}

\end{description}\end{quote}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{initialize\_adjoint\_traces() (seisflows.solver.specfem2d.specfem2d method)@\spxentry{initialize\_adjoint\_traces()}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.specfem2d.specfem2d method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.solver:seisflows.solver.specfem2d.specfem2d.initialize_adjoint_traces}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{initialize\_adjoint\_traces}}}{}{}
Puts in place “adjoint traces” expected by SPECFEM
Adjoint traces are initialized by writing zeros for all channels.
(even the ones that are not actually in use, as required by
specfem) Ex: Ux, Uy, Uz even if only Uy is used
Channels actually in use during an inversion or migration will be
overwritten with nonzero values later on.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{kernel\_databases (seisflows.solver.specfem2d.specfem2d attribute)@\spxentry{kernel\_databases}\spxextra{seisflows.solver.specfem2d.specfem2d attribute}}

\subsection{seisflows.system.lsf\_lg module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:module-seisflows.system.lsf_lg}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows-system-lsf-lg-module}}\index{seisflows.system.lsf\_lg (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.system.lsf\_lg}\spxextra{module}}\index{lsf\_lg (class in seisflows.system.lsf\_lg)@\spxentry{lsf\_lg}\spxextra{class in seisflows.system.lsf\_lg}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows.system.lsf_lg.lsf_lg}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.system.lsf\_lg.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{lsf\_lg}}}
Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows.system.base.base}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.system.base.base}}}}}

An interface through which to submit workflows, run tasks in serial or
parallel, and perform other system functions.

By hiding environment details behind a python interface layer, these
classes provide a consistent command set across different computing
environments.

Intermediate files are written to a global scratch path PATH.SCRATCH,
which must be accessible to all compute nodes.

Optionally, users can provide a local scratch path PATH.LOCAL if each
compute node has its own local filesystem.

For important additional information, please see
\sphinxurl{http://seisflows.readthedocs.org/en/latest/manual/manual.html\#system-configuration}

\subsection{seisflows.system.slurm\_lg module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:module-seisflows.system.slurm_lg}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows-system-slurm-lg-module}}\index{seisflows.system.slurm\_lg (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.system.slurm\_lg}\spxextra{module}}\index{slurm\_lg (class in seisflows.system.slurm\_lg)@\spxentry{slurm\_lg}\spxextra{class in seisflows.system.slurm\_lg}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows.system.slurm_lg.slurm_lg}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.system.slurm\_lg.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{slurm\_lg}}}
Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.system:seisflows.system.base.base}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.system.base.base}}}}}

An interface through which to submit workflows, run tasks in serial or
parallel, and perform other system functions.

By hiding environment details behind a python interface layer, these
classes provide a consistent command set across different computing
environments.

Intermediate files are written to a global scratch path PATH.SCRATCH,
which must be accessible to all compute nodes.

Optionally, users can provide a local scratch path PATH.LOCAL if each
compute node has its own local filesystem.

For important additional information, please see
\sphinxurl{http://seisflows.readthedocs.org/en/latest/manual/manual.html\#system-configuration}
\index{check() (seisflows.system.slurm\_lg.slurm\_lg method)@\spxentry{check()}\spxextra{seisflows.system.slurm\_lg.slurm\_lg method}}

\item {}

\item {}

\index{update() (seisflows.tools.seismic.Minmax method)@\spxentry{update()}\spxextra{seisflows.tools.seismic.Minmax method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.seismic.Minmax.update}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{update}}}{\sphinxoptional{\emph{E}}, \emph{**F}}{{ $\rightarrow$ None.  Update D from dict/iterable E and F.}}
If E present and has a .keys() method, does:     for k in E: D{[}k{]} = E{[}k{]}
If E present and lacks .keys() method, does:     for (k, v) in E: D{[}k{]} = v
In either case, this is followed by: for k in F: D{[}k{]} = F{[}k{]}

\end{fulllineitems}


\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{seisflows.tools.signal module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:module-seisflows.tools.signal}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows-tools-signal-module}}\index{seisflows.tools.signal (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.tools.signal}\spxextra{module}}\index{correlate() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{correlate()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mask() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{mask()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.signal.mask}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.tools.signal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mask}}}{\emph{slope}, \emph{const}, \emph{offset}, \emph{time\_scheme}, \emph{length=400}}{}
Constructs tapered mask that can be applied to trace to
mute early or late arrivals.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mute\_early\_arrivals() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{mute\_early\_arrivals()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.signal.mute_early_arrivals}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.tools.signal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mute\_early\_arrivals}}}{\emph{traces}, \emph{slope}, \emph{const}, \emph{time\_scheme}, \emph{s\_coords}, \emph{r\_coords}}{}
Applies tapered mask to record section, muting early arrivals

Signals arriving before
\begin{quote}

SLOPE * \textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} + CONST
\end{quote}

are muted, where slope is has units of velocity**-1,
CONST has units of time, and
\textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} is distance between source and receiver.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mute\_late\_arrivals() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{mute\_late\_arrivals()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.signal.mute_late_arrivals}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.tools.signal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mute\_late\_arrivals}}}{\emph{traces}, \emph{slope}, \emph{const}, \emph{time\_scheme}, \emph{s\_coords}, \emph{r\_coords}}{}
Applies tapered mask to record section, muting late arrivals

Signals arriving after
\begin{quote}

SLOPE * \textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} + CONST
\end{quote}

are muted, where SLOPE is has units of velocity**-1,
CONST has units of time, and
\textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} is distance between source and receiver.

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mute\_long\_offsets() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{mute\_long\_offsets()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.signal.mute_long_offsets}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.tools.signal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mute\_long\_offsets}}}{\emph{traces}, \emph{dist}, \emph{s\_coords}, \emph{r\_coords}}{}
Mutes traces having
\begin{quote}

\textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} \textgreater{} DIST
\end{quote}

where \textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} is the offset between source and receiver and
DIST is a user-supplied cutoff

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{mute\_short\_offsets() (in module seisflows.tools.signal)@\spxentry{mute\_short\_offsets()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.tools.signal}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.tools:seisflows.tools.signal.mute_short_offsets}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.tools.signal.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{mute\_short\_offsets}}}{\emph{traces}, \emph{dist}, \emph{s\_coords}, \emph{r\_coords}}{}
Mutes traces having
\begin{quote}

\textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} \textless{} DIST
\end{quote}

where \textbar{}\textbar{} s - r \textbar{}\textbar{} is the offset between source and receiver and
DIST is a user-supplied cutoff

\end{fulllineitems}

\subsection{seisflows.workflow.inversion module}
\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:module-seisflows.workflow.inversion}}\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:seisflows-workflow-inversion-module}}\index{seisflows.workflow.inversion (module)@\spxentry{seisflows.workflow.inversion}\spxextra{module}}\index{inversion (class in seisflows.workflow.inversion)@\spxentry{inversion}\spxextra{class in seisflows.workflow.inversion}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion}}\pysigline{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{class }}\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.workflow.inversion.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{inversion}}}
Bases: {\hyperref[\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:seisflows.workflow.base.base}]{\sphinxcrossref{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.workflow.base.base}}}}}

Waveform inversion base class

Peforms iterative nonlinear inversion and provides a base class on top
of which specialized strategies can be implemented.

To allow customization, the inversion workflow is divided into generic
methods such as ‘initialize’, ‘finalize’, ‘evaluate\_function’,
‘evaluate\_gradient’, which can be easily overloaded.

Calls to forward and adjoint solvers are abstracted through the ‘solver’
interface so that various forward modeling packages can be used
interchangeably.

Commands for running in serial or parallel on a workstation or cluster
are abstracted through the ‘system’ interface.
\index{check() (seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion method)@\spxentry{check()}\spxextra{seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion method}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion.check}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{check}}}{}{}
Checks parameters and paths

\end{fulllineitems}

\index{checkpoint() (seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion method)@\spxentry{checkpoint()}\spxextra{seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion method}}

\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows.workflow:seisflows.workflow.inversion.inversion.setup}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{setup}}}{}{}
Lays groundwork for inversion.
Runs setup method for preprocess, postprocess, optimize and also
for the solver through the system: system.run(‘solver’,’setup’)
This will copy user supplied data or generate it from a
‘real’ model supplied
This will setup the mesh for the initial model supplied
If path LOCAL is supplied this is done even at iteration \textgreater{} 1

\end{fulllineitems}

Thrifty inversion subclass

Provides savings over conventional inversion by carrying over forward
simulations from line search

The results of ‘inversion’ and ‘thrifty\_inversion’ should be exactly the
same

\index{custom\_import() (in module seisflows.config)@\spxentry{custom\_import()}\spxextra{in module seisflows.config}}

\begin{fulllineitems}
\phantomsection\label{\detokenize{ref/seisflows:seisflows.config.custom_import}}\pysiglinewithargsret{\sphinxcode{\sphinxupquote{seisflows.config.}}\sphinxbfcode{\sphinxupquote{custom\_import}}}{\emph{*args}}{}
Imports SeisFlows module and extracts class of same name. For example,
\begin{quote}

custom\_import(‘workflow’, ‘inversion’)
\end{quote}

imports ‘seisflows.workflow.inversion’ and, from this module, extracts
class ‘inversion’.

\end{fulllineitems}
